questions.answer_description:
Explanation -
http://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/server.111/b28310/diag001.htm#ADMIN11008
The Automatic Diagnostic Repository (ADR) is a directory structure that is stored outside of the database. It is therefore available for problem diagnosis when the database is down.
The ADR root directory is known as ADR base. Its location is set by the DIAGNOSTIC_DEST initialization parameter. If this parameter is omitted or left null, the database sets DIAGNOSTIC_DEST upon startup as follows:
If environment variable ORACLE_BASE is set, DIAGNOSTIC_DEST is set to the directory designated by ORACLE_BASE.
If environment variable ORACLE_BASE is not set, DIAGNOSTIC_DEST is set to ORACLE_HOME/log.
questions.question_text:
The environmental variable oracle_Base is set to /u01/app/oracle and oracle_home is set to /u01/app/oracle/product/12.1.0/db 1.
You want to check the diagnostic files created as part of the Automatic Diagnostic Repository (ADR). Examine the initialization parameters set in your database.

NAMETYPEVALUE -
---------------- ------------------- -------------------
audit_file_deststring/u01/app/oracle/admin/eml2rep/adump
background_dump_deststring
core_dump_deststring
db_create_file_deststring
db_recovery_file_deststring/u01/app/oracle/fast_recovery_area diagnostic_deststring
What is the location of the ADR base?

discussion.content: Answer C
I think C is the correct

answer is C!!!
see link
The ADR root directory is known as ADR base. Its location is set by the DIAGNOSTIC_DEST initialization parameter. If this parameter is omitted or left null, the database sets DIAGNOSTIC_DEST upon startup as follows:

If environment variable ORACLE_BASE is set, DIAGNOSTIC_DEST is set to the directory designated by ORACLE_BASE.

If environment variable ORACLE_BASE is not set, DIAGNOSTIC_DEST is set to ORACLE_HOME/log.
Answer C. It's in explanation "If environment variable =>ORACLE_BASE is set<=, DIAGNOSTIC_DEST is set to the directory designated by ORACLE_BASE"

choices.C: Corrupted blocks in the data files are checked and repaired before performing the database backup.
choices.B: Only those data files that have corrupted blocks are backed up.
choices.D: The database is checked for physically corrupt blocks and any corrupted blocks are repaired.
choices.A: Corrupted blocks, if any, are repaired in the backup created.

discussion.content: Should be D
Answer is D
The correct answer is D https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/backup.111/b28270/rcmblock.htm#BRADV89785

The correct answer is D
 When you run BACKUP VALIDATE, RMAN reads the files to be backed up in their entirety, as it would during a real backup. RMAN does not, however, actually produce any backup sets or image copies.

Answer is D.
BACKUP VALIDATE DATABASE - Checks for corruption.
Recover Corruption List - Repairs corrupt blocks listed in the V$DATABASE_BLOCK_CORRUPT view and then purges them from the view list.

questions.question_text:
You are connected to a pluggable database (PDB) as a common user with the sysdba privilege. The PDB is open and you issue the shutdown immediate command.
What is the outcome?

discussion.content: B: There is no closed Status in a PDB. PDB can have Mount/Read Write/Read Only.
Answer A is selected by closing the eyes and touching the screen randomly to select the answer.

A is correct
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/SQPUG/ch_twelve042.htm#SQPUG125

IMMEDIATE
Does not wait for current calls to complete or users to disconnect from the database.
Further connects are prohibited. The database is closed and dismounted. The instance is shutdown and no instance recovery is required on the next database startup.
No doubt its B
Answer B
I think the correct answer is B. For a pdb, when it closed, it is in mount status

choices.B: The PDB is placed and left in the mount state.
choices.C: The command executes only if the common user is granted the set container privilege for the PDB.
choices.A: The PDB is closed and left in the unmount state.
choices.D: The command results in an error because the PDB can be shut down only by a local user.

discussion.content:
ABE 
cant use direct path (C)
cant create tables (D)

comments.content: c incorret no DIRECT PATH only also conventional

discussion.content:
ACE is correct 
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B19306_01/server.102/b14215/ldr_concepts.htm#i1004619
Use either conventional or direct path loading. While conventional path loading is very flexible, direct path loading provides superior loading performance. See Chapter 11.
ABE is correct
ABE 100%
i think its ADE
ABE confirmed

is ADE correct or ABE?

im confused

comments.content: ABE, sql loader can not create table, it just loads data into table.

discussion.content: I think the correct answer is BDE

choices.B: It can be used to extract and reorganize data from external files, and then load it into a table.
choices.E: It can be used to generate unique sequential values in specified columns while loading data.
choices.C: It can be used to load data from external files using direct path only.
choices.A: It can be used to load data from multiple external files into multiple tables.
choices.D: It can be used to create tables using data that is stored in external files.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about the SQL*Loader utility?

discussion.content: I think D is also possible; Though it is mentioned as a performance factor of the Read phase, is leads to more input for the write phase.
BE confirmed
BE correct
I think BE is right..
Answer AD

comments.content: its B E. i had read about this before
Answer A would make no sense; Backup optimization is about skipping files that already have been backed up.

discussion.content: I think the correct answer is AD

questions.question_text:
While performing database backup to tape via the media manager interface, you notice that tape streaming is not happening because RMAN is not sending data blocks fast enough to the tape drive.
Which two actions would you take for tape streaming to happen during the backup?

choices.B: Configure the channel to increase maxopenfiles.
choices.C: Configure a backup policy by using incremental backups.
choices.F: Configure large_pool, if not done already. Alternatively, you can increase the size of large_pool.
choices.D: Configure the channel to increase capacity with the rate parameter.
choices.E: Configure the channel to adjust the tape buffer size by using the 3LKSIZE option.
